course.subject: SHSS
course.name: Understanding China, 1700-2000: A Data Analytic Approach
course.description: The purpose of this course is to summarize some of the new directions in Chinese history and Chinese social science during the last two decades. The course eschews the standard chronological narrative arc for an analytic approach that focuses on specific data sets and distinguishes between data measurement and the production of new facts, and how these new facts complicate our understanding of current social theories. The primary motivation for this course design is to stimulate critical thinking, and to encourage students to question received wisdom.

reviews.author: helloworld
reviews.comment_content: The course discusses various topics on social history in the late imperial China using a 'big data' approach, ie. using many statistics. the contents can be divided to 2 parts: the first part is more about social stratification in imperial china, topics discussed include imperial exam system vs. exams and university education in PRC,property distribution, land reforms, etc. the second part discusses topics related to demographics, eg. the birth controls in imperial china.
reviews.comment_teaching: Lecture videos are used in this course, one has to finish watching lecture videos before attending classes, which are used as a tutorial session at which each group has to do a 10-min presentation every lesson and discussions are made afterwards. In general, the professor is kind and knows a lot to discuss whatever raised by students.
reviews.comment_grading: the grade of the course is made up of weekly 250-word essay discussing topics taught that week, presentations every lesson, online quizzes and participation, 25% each. Feedback is given back before next submission of assignments, grading should be good, probably due to the small class size and presence of students from UVA, my final grade is A.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is quite heavy for a 3-credit course. Typically there is 50-100 page of readings per lesson (3 lessons a week), which you have to read to prepare your presentation. Presentation skills are expected and will be discussed after the presentation.

reviews.author: USTP
reviews.title: Good grade but heavy workloads
reviews.comment_content:
The content was relatively interesting, it was divided into 3 topics, which were
1. Who are we
2. Who gets education
3. Who gets wealth

But the focus of these three topics are confusing. Given too many reading materials while professor was talking something literally different.

I suggest you to look through the content yourself, it could be fun.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Video was provided before class. They were talking about the lecture slide, so actually you just need to look at the lecture slide.

Professors tried to raise up discussion so he did not talk about lecture slide anymore, but it felt like that he did not prepare anything to talk about so there was no keen discussion on one topic actually.

Then, after the first two days, we did presentation every day. It was a challenge as we do not really get enough time to look through the cases deeply.

We only have discussion after the presentation.

In class, the professor fall asleep all the time when students were presenting. So I do not really know who was grading the presentation.
reviews.comment_grading:
1. Presentation and Writing= 70% of Final
2. Discussion= 15% of Final
3. Group Teamwork (evaluation marks given by group-mates) = 15% of Final

I got a good grade at last but I do not know any marks at all.
reviews.comment_workload: Presentation/ writing as everyday assignment (but the writing group still needs to present)

reviews.author: chimz
reviews.title: 我好想做好，但我唔知點樣先可以做得好
reviews.comment_content:
分咗三個大單元:
Who are we? (5 weeks) 係關於殺嬰、婚姻、生育、人倫關係
Who gets education? (4 weeks) 分時段: 清朝、民國、當代中國，最後以機會不平等作結
Who gets wealth (2 weeks) 分時段: 晚清、國共內戰新中國成立初期，以土地分配為主軸
reviews.comment_teaching: 呢一個係flip-learning嘅科，簡單或史實會係video個度講一次，其餘要睇Reading。而學生就係透過小組功課，就住一個focusing question去認識呢一個topic，組組題目都唔一樣。上堂嘅時候，大家就係分享自己組研習到嘅成果，跟住李教授再俾意見。同學嘅提問都係一個幫助自己學習嘅方法，但呢個要取決於大家對題目嘅興趣同埋理解。李教授係針對內容去俾意見，而其他導師就針對presen嘅設計、流程俾意見。
reviews.comment_grading:
我相信都唔會爛，始終70%分數係小組一齊攞架，UG係fall semester讀只係佔少數，大多都係PG，而PG最低嘅合格分數係C，所以UG間接係有一定程度好處。

但最主力改功課都係導師，我曾經都有問過佢地攞意見，但我唔覺得有幫助，我唔知有咩方法可以做好d功課，自問該做嘅都做咗，所以係評卷同埋俾意見方面好失望。

Grading俾C嘅原因主要係我攞唔到好意見。
reviews.comment_workload:
個個禮拜都要功課，係小組做嘅,小組係導師編架，UG一組一至二個，全組6~7個，其他全部都係PG，而組員一齊攞同一樣分數

按: 始終大家都呢科目的唔同，有人係fulfill MSc (GCS) requirement, 有人係fulfill UG CC requirement, 都有人係想透過呢個course同院長熟起嚟，所以係分咗組你自己都要有心理準備，胸襟要闊d, 唔好為咗一次半次分數，而令到其他同學覺得你好霸道，如果唔係peer evaluation有排你受。

70% Weekly Assignment (incl. 5 group presentation and 5 group writings)
Group writing都要上堂做簡短口頭報告 (One Slide Presentation)
15% Discussion / In-class performance
15% Peer evaluation

所以你的小組如何，你的命運也必如何，我俾workload C係唔想大家有錯覺，有d人可能好命遇到好組員，實會俾A架，調番轉就實俾E，所以俾C去中和一下啦 :)

reviews.author: JimmyLeung1998
reviews.comment_content: This course focuses on the social and economic transformation over the last few decades. Various qualitative and quantitative research results are provided. After studying all these materials and do your homework well, You would expect to have a better understanding on the big picture of how and what does China changes. And I would say as a common core course, it really helps promoting the thinking-and-questioning sides of social science. No wonder why students can take this to fulfill SSC-SA/SSC-H requirement!
reviews.comment_teaching: It is not an usual face-to-face lecture course, but more like a seminar-course style. Before each lecture, you would watch a short video clip by Professor Lee to get some idea about the theme of discussion in that week. Then you would have to read the online materials. In this mostly self-learning process, the professors seems more like a advisor or a grader than a teacher. In some senses, the "teaching" part here may not be applicable.
reviews.comment_grading:
Here is the grading scheme at the year I take this course
35% -- 5 group ppt presentations, 15 - 20 min each... (1)
35% -- 5 group essays, 1000 words each ... (2)
15% -- peer assessment within group ... (3)
10% -- Discussion on other groups work ... (4)
  5% -- Individual performance ... (5)

(1) (2):
There are around 5 essays and 5 presentation throughout the semester for each group. You need to work well with your team to get a higher scores. Also, as the course in fall semster is usually colisted with the post-graduate course MGCS5001, your English proficiency is somehow assumed. If you even found those LANG 1000-level courses (which are usually only deal with one or two individual term paper) difficult or boring, then you would be promised to not end well in terms of your final grade


(3):
As long as you keep being a good team player and really do your research and writing part well, you should have no problems with this,

(4):
In each week, there are serveral questions/topics assigned to students. Total number of questions depends on the class size. But one thing for sure is that different groups would be paired up randomly and each pair would receive the same question at that week, so that one group would do writing and the other would do presentation on that topic. And that's why in each week, apart from doing your weekly assignment, you would also be asked to take a look on the other group work before the class meeting to prepare for the discussion. On some weeks you would be confident enough to question the validity of the other's work and in another unlucky days you may find your opponents did a better job that you and you just have to defend your work and to hope the professor would not give you a low score for this.

(5):
Actually that's the only part I am not so sure how it works Maybe somehow your performance on the general in-class discussion and your ability to raise up a good-quality question also count for the grade.

And from the above, you would find no midterm or final exams. And this is because there are none of them in this course!!!! I would say it is one of the good things about the grading.

Btw, my final grade is A. I would say with hard working really comes a very good returns.
reviews.comment_workload:
As I mentioned before, each week you have to work on the written essay / oral presentation and find some mistakes (...) on another group's work. It is actually quite heavy for a 3-credit common core course. At the first few weeks you may even be shocked by the huge amount of reading materials. But after some days you should be clever enough to know that some materials that are not useful for your assignment could simply be ignored. All you have to do to reduce workload and enhance the quality of your work is just to focus on the right direction and find enough source to support you arguments. And I think this is one of the most important intended learning outcomes of this course. Later if you start your own research on whatever areas, you may find this 1-semester-long research experience useful. So just not to be scared by the possibly huge worload, but try to be open-minded toward this kind of research-seminar-style-course.
